Issues.Title: Setting IncludePackageReferencesDuringMarkupCompilation with a custom BaseIntermediateOutputPath causes build to fail
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 5.0.102
 
 **Problem description:**
I tried following the suggestion in #3963 in order to pull in a source generator nuget to a wpf project.  Upon doing so (setting `IncludePackageReferencesDuringMarkupCompilation` to `true`), my build fails with the following:

```
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\5.0.102\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\targets\Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets(241,5):
error NETSDK1004: Assets file 'C:\Dev\pkgref-bugs\Objects\wpf-app_smqwgw3w_wpftmp\project.assets.json' not found.
Run a NuGet package restore to generate this file. [C:\Dev\pkgref-bugs\wpf-app\wpf-app_smqwgw3w_wpftmp.csproj]
```
 
I noticed that if I stop using a custom `BaseIntermediateOutputPath` for my projects, then I'm able to build successfully.

 **Expected behavior:**
I should be able to use source generators with wpf applications and use a custom `BaseIntermediateOutputPath`
 
 **Minimal repro:**
- Add a package reference to a source generator in a wpf project
- Set the `IncludePackageReferencesDuringMarkupCompilation` property to be true
- Create a `Directory.Build.props` file to set `BaseIntermediateOutputPath`.  I used `..\Objects\$(MSBuildProjectName)`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Setting IncludePackageReferencesDuringMarkupCompilation with a custom BaseIntermediateOutputPath causes build to fail" (#4067)

Issues.Title: .Net Core 3.0/.Net Framework WPF Resource in C# shared items project
Issues.Body:
Hello,
I have a c# shared items project, between a .net core and .net framework wpf app.  And trying to share an image as follows in the shared .projitems. Both main projects dont' seem to pick this up. In fact, the IDE shows a disable status for each file. IDE seems to light up if it's a 'content' file.

```
Contents of .projitems ..

  <ItemGroup>
    <Resource Include="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)Images\Background.jpg" />
    <Resource Include="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)Images\Checkbox_checked.png" />
  </ItemGroup>
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".Net Core 3.0/.Net Framework WPF Resource in C# shared items project" (#4066)

Issues.Title: WPF support for ARM64: Enable WPF for ARM64 builds on the public WPF repo
Issues.Body:
Complete any remaining updates and turn on ARM64 builds in the WPF repo.  (ARM64 packages must already be flowing from dotnet-wpf-int.) 

Requires https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/4034, https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/4035, https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/4041, and https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/4042.

Issues.Title: Cannot add reference to DLL project
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/Cannot-add-reference-to-DLL-project/1254036?preview=true)._ --- [severity:It's more difficult to complete my work] [regression] [worked-in:15.9.20] I have a WPF application targeting .Net 5 built using VS2019 Preview 16.8.0 I add a class library to the project. This class library will contain XAML loaded dynamically at runtime. The XAML will not compile because of a missing reference: Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App.WPF (this reference is automatically added to the EXE project but not to the DLL project). Right-click Dependencies restricts which references can be added. It has "Add project reference", "Add COM reference", etc, but no "Add reference" like in previous versions of VS. See screenshot in attached UNTITLED. PNG file. Workaround: hand-edit the . CSPROJ file (which I have to do to multiple DLL projects) --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 11/18/2020, 01:46 AM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Issues.Title: Fix incremental build for WPF projects with dotnet.exe
Issues.Body:
This PR fixes incremental builds for WPF projects if `dotnet.exe` is used for building.

The `GetHashCode()` method of strings can produce different hash values between subsequent program runs in .NET Core and cannot be used to persist the `MarkupCompile.cache` file.

A copy of the `GetHashCode()` method from .NET Framework is now used instead.

The bug was found as part of #3876.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Fix incremental build for WPF projects with dotnet.exe" (#4053)

Issues.Title: Community PRs merged in the last month : Dec-Jan
Issues.Body:
We merged 18 community PRs from mid-Dec to mid-Jan. We expect to merge more as we grow our Development team in the next couple of months. 

1)  Remove unused local variable 'selfStyle' and related conditionals in System.Windows.StyleHelper.GetThemeStyle #4010

 2) Replace the Dictionary with HashSet in AppDomainShutdownMonitor #3932
 
3) Don't double import WinFX targets #2976
 
4) Use the new Marshal.IsTypeVisibleFromCom Api #3279
 
5) Special the capacity to improve performance #3086

6) Using readonly struct in WPF Ink module #3908
 
7) Make CustomGuids as readonly #3907
 
8) Adjust project templates to support .NET 6.0 (and default to it) #3976

9)  Added label "ResourceKey" to trace details when resource is not found #3493

10) Remove always-true condition #3009

11) Reduce memory usage by Array.Empty #3085
 
12) Call SHA1.HashData static helper instead of instantiating SHA1CSP #3318
 
13) Fix a wrong property name in a comment #3926
 
14) Set the lock object as readonly #939
 
15) Remove backup file for solution #2965
 
16) Use Array.Empty instead of creating list in ResourceDictionaryDiagnostics #3851
 
17) Fix Grid SetFinalSize method comment #3909
 
18)  Add clearer win32 exception information in SplashScreen CreateWindow #3923
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Community PRs merged in the last month : Dec-Jan" (#4052)
